p.content: There are two types of questions: those which require a
or
answer and those which are seeking information. This section considers the main clause and embedded clause varieties of both types.

In English, main clause Yes/No questions are formed by moving an auxiliary verb in front of the subject. Other languages use a Yes/No question marker or special complementizer instead of the fronted auxiliary. This is the case in embedded Yes/No questions in English; no auxiliary fronting is allowed but
or
fills the complementizer position. Since languages may act differently in main clause and embedded clause Yes/No questions, each will be covered separately.
Main clause and embedded Yes/No questions may be formed differently with respect to auxiliary movement and question markers or complementizers.
English examples of main clause Yes/No questions, showing the required fronting of an auxiliary, include:
p.langData: Are you going to the store?
Will Sue buy the present for her mother?
p.content: and
p.langData: Could the boy have hit the ball?

p.content: examples of main clause Yes/No questions include:
As the examples show,

there are one or more question markers or complementizers

to the verb in the Yes/No question as a suffix.
to the verb in the Yes/No question, some as prefixes and some as suffixes.
either to the beginning or end of the Yes/No question as a phrasal clitic, or to the verb in the Yes/No question as an affix.

English examples of Yes/No questions in embedded clauses, showing the presence of the question markers or complementizers, include:
p.langData: I wonder whether she will come
I will know if she goes
p.content: and
p.langData: Sue wonders whether the boy could have hit the ball

p.content: These markers are:
Content questions differ from Yes/No questions in that they contain an interrogative word or phrase, known as wh-phrases in English because they almost all begin with
. In some languages, some or all of these interrogatives are expressed as affixes. The corresponding interrogative words or phrases or affixes in
are shown in
Content questions differ from Yes/No questions in that they contain an interrogative word or phrase. The interrogative words or phrases or affixes in
are shown in

Depending on the basic word order of the language, content questions may be formed with or without fronting an interrogative phrase. Head-final languages (SOV, OVS, and OSV) usually do not have movement of an interrogative phrase in content questions, while head-initial languages (SVO, VOS, and VSO) usually require fronting of an interrogative phrase.

In languages without fronting for interrogatives, the phrase structure of a content question is either the same as a Yes/No question with a question marker or auxiliary in the complementizer position or just the same as a normal sentence. In either case, the interrogative phrase appears in its normal argument positon. Many SOV languages optionally allow movement of an interrogative phrase to the position immediately before the verb.
In both main clause and embedded content questions in
, an interrogative phrase

case.caseText: does not front; it simply remains in place.
may remain in place or it may move to the position immediately before the verb.
moves to the beginning of the clause.

p.content: Main clause content questions in English require an interrogative phrase to be fronted and also have an auxiliary move to the position directly after the fronted interrogrative phrase when something other than the subject is being questioned. Some examples of English main clause content questions are:
p.langData: Who might have hit the ball?
p.content: and
examples of main clause content questions include:
As the examples show,

case.caseText: there is no marker or auxiliary fronting,
there is at least one question marker or complementizer in main clause content questions.

text.content: Some of the question markers or complementizers are independent words but some attach
The question markers or complementizers are written as an independent word.
The question markers or complementizers attach
to the beginning of whatever word begins the question as phrasal proclitics.
to the beginning of whatever word begins the question or following the fronted interrogative phrase to the beginning of whatever word begins the rest of the question as phrasal proclitics.
to the beginning of whatever word begins the question as phrasal proclitics or to the end of the last word in the fronted interrogative phrase as phrasal enclitics, before the rest of the question.

to the beginning of whatever word begins the question or following the fronted interrogative phrase to the beginning of whatever word begins the rest of the question as phrasal proclitics or to the end of the last word in the fronted interrogative phrase as phrasal enclitics, before the rest of the question.
following the fronted interrogative phrase to the beginning of whatever word begins the rest of the question as phrasal proclitics.
to the end of whatever word ends the question as phrasal enclitics.

to the end of whatever word ends the question as phrasal enclitics or following the fronted interrogative phrase to the beginning of whatever word begins the rest of the question as phrasal proclitics.
to the end of whatever word ends the question or to the end of the last word in the fronted interrogative phrase, before the rest of the question, as phrasal enclitics.

to the end of whatever word ends the question or to the end of the last word in the fronted interrogative phrase, before the rest of the question, as phrasal enclitics or following the fronted interrogative phrase to the beginning of whatever word begins the rest of the question as phrasal proclitics.
to the end of the last word in the fronted interrogative phrase as phrasal enclitics, before the rest of the question.

following the fronted interrogative phrase to the beginning of whatever word begins the rest of the question as phrasal proclitics or to the end of the last word in the fronted interrogative phrase as phrasal enclitics, before the rest of the question.
either to the beginning of whatever word begins the question or to the end of whatever word ends the question as phrasal clitics.

either to the beginning of whatever word begins the question or to the end of whatever word ends the question or following the fronted interrogative phrase to the beginning of whatever word begins the rest of the question as phrasal clitics.

either to the beginning of whatever word begins the question or to the end of whatever word ends the question or to the end of the last word in the fronted interrogative phrase, before the rest of the question, as phrasal clitics.

either to the beginning of whatever word begins the question or to the end of whatever word ends the question or following the fronted interrogative phrase to the beginning of whatever word begins the rest of the question or to the end of the last word in the fronted interrogative phrase, before the rest of the question, as phrasal clitics.
to the verb in the question as a prefix.
to the verb in the question as a suffix.
to the verb in the question, some as prefixes and some as suffixes.
either to the beginning or end of the question as a phrasal clitic, or to the verb in the question as an affix.

p.content: These question markers are:

In English embedded content questions, an interrogative phrase is required to be fronted to the beginning of the embedded clause. However, in contrast to the main clause content questions, there is no auxiliary fronting. Examples of English embedded content questions include:
p.langData: I know who hit the ball
I wonder when she will come
p.content: and
p.langData: I will ask what the boy hit

p.content: examples of embedded clause content questions include:
As the examples show,

case.caseText: there is no marker or auxiliary fronting,
there is at least one question marker or complementizer in embedded clause content questions.
